resources.string:
Concepts:
 There are three concepts within programming:
 • Sequence – the ability to run instructions one after another
 • Selection – the ability to select which instructions to run 
 • Iteration – the ability to repeat instructions multiple times 
 

These concepts apply to imperative programming languages 
, like Java. There are other concepts such as functional and declarative. 
 
 Variables:
 Variables let us save values and give them names, which allows us to use them in more than one place in a program
 • To start using a variable, you have to declare it, that is, you have to tell Java (a) what sort of value it can hold (like a String, or an array of Strings) and (b) its name. Sometimes you give it an initial value as well.
 • Once you have declared a variable, you can use it in calculations.
 • You can also change its value to a new value using an assignment statement.
 
 I/O 
 When a Java program runs, it has one input device and one output device provided to it (by the system) for basic communication.
 • System.out to print out messages on the screen 
 • System.in to get input from the user 
 • Scanner - the specific Java library used to capture users input

What is Artificial Intelligence? 
 AI is the ability of digital computers or computer controlled robots to solve problems that are normally associated with the higher intellectual processing capabilities of humans. 
 
 Rational Agents: 
 • Rational behavior: doing the right thing! 
 • An agent is anything that can be viewed as perceiving its environment through sensors and acting upon that environment through actuators 
 • Abstractly, an agent is a function from percept histories to actions: [f: P*  A] 
 • For any given class of environments and tasks, we seek the agent (or class of agents) with the best performance 
 • Caveat: computational limitations make perfect rationality unachievable 
 
 Software Agent: 
 • Software agents are software programs which have intelligent behaviour and can behave autonomously. 
 • A software agent may use keystrokes, file contents etc as sensory inputs and acts on the environment by writing to files, displaying information on screen. 
 

Environment Types: 
 There are two types of environments that can be seen below. 
 Fully observable: If an agents sensors give it access to the complete state of the environment at each point in time. The agent has complete information to make the optimal decision. For example playing backgammon or chess. 
 • Partially observable – The agent only has some of the information of the environment. In these cases the agent requires internal memory to store past actions in order to make best possible decisions. 
 

There are other factors within environnment types: 
 • Deterministic- If the next state of the environment is completely determined by the current state and the action executed by the agent. 
 • Stochastic- If we are not able to predict what will happen next. 
 • Episodic- In each episode the agent receives a percept and performs a single action. The next episode does not depend on the actions in the previous episodes. 
 • Sequential- The current decision can effect future decisions.

Why are attacks more common: 
 • Increased connectivity 
 • Relatively easy to access 
 • Many more hosts online (IoT) 
 • Many more sophisticated hacking tools and methodologies exist 
 

Cyber Security definition: 
 Cybersecurity is the protection of internet-connected systems, including hardware, software and data, from cyberattacks 
 

CIA: 
 Confidentiality: Only authorised figures can view sensitive information 
 Integrity: Only authorised individuals can modify data 
 Availability: Able to serve information when needed 
 

Problem with security: /n • Scale of the problem is underestimated 
 • Nature of the threats often unknown, even to IT professionals 
 • Security policies are not sufficiently developed 
 • There is no international legislation 
 

Major factors with breaches: /n • Lots of buggy software and credulous users 
 • Money can be made from finding and exploiting vulnerabilities 
 

Terminology: 
 Asset- The records of each patient that is receiving or has received treatment. 
 Exposure- Potential financial loss from future patients who do not seek treatment because they do not trust the clinic to maintain their data. Financial loss from legal action by the sports star. Loss of reputation. 
 Vulnerability- A weak password system which makes it easy for users to set guessable passwords.User ids that are the same as names. 
 Attack- An impersonation of an authorized user. 
 Threat- An unauthorized user will gain access to the system by guessing the credentials (login name and password) of an authorized user. 
 Control- A password checking system that disallows user passwords that are proper names or words that are normally included in a dictionary.
List of topics designed to help you ace your computer science course
Widen and test your knowledge to be ahead of the curve
A timed quiz to put your knowledge of the computer science modules into practise
